schema.description: Returns an access token for a user.

for_client_id.description: Unique identifier of the API client authenticating the operation. This client needs to have the `login_client` feature, which gives it permission to call login and registration operations.

id.description: __Read-only__ Locally unique identifier of the user. This is optional if you're using the `uuid` member or the `key_attribute` member.

key_attribute.description: Name of a unique attribute in the schema. This is optional if you specify `id` or `uuid`. If you specify this, your request needs to include a `key_value` as well.

type_name.description: Name of the entity type that stores user profiles.

uuid.description: Universally unique identifier of the user profile. This is optional if you're using `id` or `key_attribute` to identify the user record.

schema.description: Returns an access token for the user.

stat.description: Status of the operation. Possible values are: `ok`, `error`, and `fail`. The value `ok` indicates that the operation was successful. The value `error` indicates that the operation couldn't complete because of a problem with the request. The value `fail` means that the operation couldn't complete because of an error with the Identity Cloud backend infrastructure. Contact your Identity Cloud representative if your request returns the `fail` status.

200.description: The response provides the Identity Cloud access token, or indicates a failure.

post.description: Returns an authorization code you can exchange for an access token and a refresh token.

schema.description: Returns an authorization code for a user. The user can then exchange this code for an access token.

for_client_id.description: Unique identifier of the API client authenticating the operation. This client needs to have the `login_client` feature, which gives it permission to call login and registration operations.

id.description: __Read-only__ Locally unique identifier of the user. This member is optional if you're using the `uuid` member or the `key_attribute` member.

key_attribute.description: Name of a unique attribute in the schema. This member is optional if you're using the `id` or `uuid` member. If you use this member your operation needs to include the `key_value` member as well.

lifetime.description: Number of seconds before the authorization code expires.

redirect_uri.description: Typically the redirect URL from the initial authorization request. If using the JavaScript SDK, this value needs to match the value of the SDK's `redirectUri` setting.

transaction_state.description: Random string in the authorization request that the operation returns when you exchange the code for an access token and a refresh token.

type_name.description: Name of the entity type that stores user profiles.

uuid.description: Universally unique identifier of the user profile. This member is optional if you're using the `id` or `key_attribute` members to identify the user record.

schema.description: Returns an authorization code. You can exchange an authorization code for an access token and a refresh token.

stat.description: Status of the operation. Possible values are: `ok`, `error`, and `fail`. The value `ok` indicates that the operation was successful. The value `error` indicates that the operation couldn't complete because of a problem with the request. The value `fail` means that the operation couldn't complete because of an error with the Identity Cloud backend infrastructure. Contact your Identity Cloud representative if your request returns the `fail` status.

post.description: Returns a verification code for setting a user profile attribute to the current date and time. This code typically verifies an email address.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Authentication API

schema.description: Returns a verification code for a user. Verification sets a timestamp on attributes such as `emailVerified`.

attribute_name.description: Name of the attribute the verification code updates.

id.description: __Read-only__ Locally unique identifier of the user. This member is optional if you're using the `uuid` member or the `key_attribute` member.

key_attribute.description: Name of a unique attribute in the schema. This member is optional if you're using the `id` or `uuid` member. If you use this member your operation needs to include the `key_value` member as well.

lifetime.description: Number of seconds before the authorization code expires.

type_name.description: Name of the entity type that stores user profiles.

uuid.description: Universally unique identifier of the user profile. This member is optional if you're using the `id` or `key_attribute` members to identify the user record.

schema.description: Returns a verification code. Verification codes set a timestamp value in a user profile to the current time.

stat.description: Status of the operation. Possible values are: `ok`, `error`, and `fail`. The value `ok` indicates that the operation was successful. The value `error` indicates that the operation couldn't complete because of a problem with the request. The value `fail` means that the operation couldn't complete because of an error with the Identity Cloud backend infrastructure. Contact your Identity Cloud representative if your request returns the `fail` status.

post.description: Uses a one-time verification code to set an attribute value to the current time. Note that you don't need to specify which attribute you're updating. That's because the you specify the attribute name when you request the verification code. Use the [Get a verification code](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-auth/reference/post-access-getverificationcode) operation to return a verification code. You don't need any authorization to run this operation.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Authentication API

schema.description: Uses a verification code to set a date-time attribute to the current time. You typically use this operation to verify email addresses.

verification_code.description: Verification code from the [Get verification code](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-auth/reference/post-access-getverificationcode) operation.

schema.description: Uses a verification code to set a date-time attribute to the current time. You typically use this operation to verify email addresses.

schema.description: Completes a social login.

client_id.description: Unique identifier of the API client authenticating the operation. This client needs to have the `login_client` feature, which gives it permission to call login and registration operations.

flow.description: Name of the API client's flow.

flow_version.description: Version number of the flow in the `flow` member. Note that you can't set the value of this member to `HEAD`, a shorthand way to refer to the most recent version of the flow. Instead, you need to specify a valid version number.

locale.description: RFC 5646 language code for the profile management process. The locale determines the language for any messages the user sees and for any emails sent to that user. See [Supported languages and locales](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/hosted-login-supported-languages-and-locales-1) for more information.

merge_token.description: If a previous operation fails with an error code of `380 email_address_in_use`, you can use this to merge the social account from that operation with an existing account. For example, suppose a user logs on by using Facebook, and Facebook returns `karim.nafir@example.com`, an email address used by an existing Identity Cloud account. In that case, set `merge_token` to add Facebook to the existing account as a social login identity provider. The value is the token from the previous operation. See [Additional Authentication API examples](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/additional-authentication-api-examples) for sample code.

redirect_uri.description: Typically the redirect URL from the initial authorization request. If using the JavaScript SDK, this value needs to match the value of the SDK's `redirectUri` setting.

registration_form.description: Name of the social registration form.

response_type.description: Determines the item or items a user receives following a successful authentication. Allowed values are `code`, `token`, and `code_with_token`. With `code`, the user receives an authorization code. With `token`, the user receives an access token. With `code_with_token` the user receives both an authorization code and an access token. If you leave this member out the user receives an access token.

token.description: One-time token for social authentication. The API client's social login application passes this token to your token URL.

post.description:
Completes traditional login by using an email address and password. See [JavaScript SDK registration overview](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/javascript-sdk-registration-overview) for a comparison of social logins and registrations and traditional logins and registrations.

Note that your request can use fields not shown in this documentation. In fact, you can use any fields that appear on the sign-in form. For example, suppose your form includes a custom field `membershipLevel` that you’d like to submit as part of the login process. In that case, create a key-value pair for `membershipLevel`, specifying the field name and the field value: `"membershipLevel=gold"`.

 You don't need any authorization to call this operation.

locale.description: RFC 5646 language code for the profile management process. The locale determines the language for any messages the user sees and for any emails sent to that user. See [Supported languages and locales](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/hosted-login-supported-languages-and-locales-1) for more information.

merge_token.description: If a previous operation fails with an error code of `380 email_address_in_use`, you can use this to merge the social account from that operation with an existing account. For example, suppose a user logs on by using Facebook, and Facebook returns `karim.nafir@example.com`, an email address in use by an existing Identity Cloud account. In that case, set `merge_token` to add Facebook to the existing account as a social login identity provider. The value is the token from the previous operation. redirect_uri.description: Typically the redirect URL from the initial authorization request. If using the JavaScript SDK, this values needs to match the value of the SDK's `redirectUri` setting.

response_type.description: Determines the set of items a user receives following a successful authentication. Allowed values are `code`, `token`, and `code_with_token`. With `code`, the user receives an authorization code. With `token`, the user receives an access token. With `code_with_token` the user receives both an authorization code and an access token. If you leave this member out, the user receives an access token.

post.description:
Creates an account by using social registration. To use this operation, first make a call to the [Complete social login](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-auth/reference/post-oauth-auth-native) operation which logs a user in to a social login identity provider. You can then use the social login token from that operation as the value of the `token` member in this operation.

Note that your request can use fields that aren't in this documentation. In fact, you can use any fields on the registration form. For example, suppose you've a custom field `membershipLevel` that you’d like to submit as part of the registration process. In that case, create a key-value pair for `membershipLevel`, specifying the field name and the field value: `"membershipLevel=gold"`.

 You don't need any authorization to call this operation.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Authentication API

post.description:
Updates a user profile. This operation only updates the user profile attributes in the request. User profile attributes not in the request are left as they are.

To update a profile you can use any of the fields on the form. For example, if your form includes the `firstName` field you can update that field by including a line like this in your request: `"firstName": "Matthew"`.

If you need to set the value of a boolean field to `false`, don't include that field in your operation, and don't set the value to `false`. In other words, the following syntax _doesn't_ set the boolean field `newsletterSubscriber` to `false`: `newsletterSubscriber=false`.

Instead, the preceding code actually sets `newsletterSubscriber` to `true`. That's due to the way that the Authentication API handles boolean values. If a boolean attribute is in your request, its value is automatically set to `true` regardless of the value in the request. If the attribute isn't in the request, the value is set to `false`.

You don't need any authorization to call this operation.
